fields.value: What Happens to Banks When House Prices Fall? U.S. Regional Busts of the 1980s and 1990s

authorAffiliation.value: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

dsDescriptionValue.value: The recent rapid appreciation of house prices in many U.S.  markets has prompted concern over the possible effects of a sharp  decline in prices, especially for commercial banks and other real  estate lenders. This article examines regional real estate booms and  busts in the 1980s and 1990s: Only about half of state house price  booms were followed by a severe decline in prices, but large house  price declines experienced high loan default rates and, thus, low  profit and high failure rates. Although U.S. banks may have become  more exposed to residential real estate recently, they appear less  vulnerable to a decline in house prices than banks in states with large price declines in the earlier period.
